Yesterday was the big race. My son was stroke of the Grammar First VIII.   They didn't win - but they beat the arch enemy - my old school - Sydney Boys High School.
That, and years as a surf lifesaver giving me the experience of knowing where to look.

It was the life-savers third patrol and his first rescue. So he was thrilled.  They were both pretty German tourists - but he got the one that was even more incandescently beautiful.   I do not know whether he was single.

I watched them from the shore figuring they would need to be rescued. I sent a kid to get the surf lifesavers.  I did the easy one (close to the shore) after taking a child's body board from a family on the beach.   The lifesaver did the hard one - with a rescued tube.   3/5

The one at Palm was where the central flags normally are. But the beach was closed. There were plenty of people swimming and I ent in with flippers - getting shifted down the beach.  Two people had been swept more than 100m further down the beach than me. 2/3

The two at Bronte were in the same "hole", a surprisingly deep patch surrounded by sand-bars where the current was dropping the unwary.   The lifesavers have put someone there to watch. I suspect they will pull out a few more before today is over.  1/2
Bronte can be dangerous. Always has been. Flag placement not unusual. The lifesavers were busy.

The one at Palm was a German tourist. An incandescently pretty young woman which only served to tease a married man.  Today were both newer Australians, one woman, one man. The man had body-shape of extreme gym junky. Simply huge muscles. They sink I gather.

I spent whole seasons as a volunteer surf lifesaver without doing a rescue.  I  have had two brief casual visits to the beach in the last week and did three rescues.   cc  Details, one at Palm last Sunday, two at Bronte today.
